reviewText: Simply beautiful and yet sad, I didnt want to watch this last episode because I didnt want to say goodbye, it hurt to see these wonderful characters go, they had become dearly loved friends, (yes even Londo! )so  it was with great reluctance that I watched one of my favourite shows end.This finale to the B5 series is about saying goodbye, it is told giving  us a chance to make our own farewells reflecting on the many hours of  enjoyment that the B5 crew have given us, we see a future that has moved  on, as it should, (but you cant help grieving! )I will miss this  wonderful series, a beautiful end and a tribute to this scifi classic, it  will stay with me forever (My eyes are starting to blur where is the damn  tissues! )I urge any scifi/B5 virgins out there to watch this excellent  series!  you will understand why this show has a strong and loyal  following. BABYLON 5 FOREVER!
summary: GOODBYE AND THANKYOU SO MUCH J. MICHAEL STRACZYNSKI!

reviewText: The first time I watched these episodes was more than two years ago. Occasionally ,I take the time to rerun it on the video to reminiscence, reflect, and to see things in a wider perspective, this two episodes give.This first of two, "Objects at Rest" ,sums up the five years saga; after all the wars, peace treaties, happiness ,sadness, blood and tears, it's time for the leading characters to move on.Sheridan and Delen are heading for Minbar to the new home base of the Alliance. G'kar and Lita are to explore together the galaxy. Garibaldi and Liz are leaving for Mars, sto marry and manage Edgar's Enterprises. Lando has already left permanently, in an earlier episode to face the darkest destiny of them all. Almost none of the familiar and loved figures stay. There is a distinct feeling of ending. Things are never going to be the same around here.Babylon 5 did matter(besides from the Babylon universe). It touched the hearts of so many, which will miss dearly all that this TV series represented. Up till now, I feel this end symbolized not only the finale of a major Sci fi show, but also the end of the last vintage television production. .I haven't seen anything that even gets close to the standard this series had set.I cannot end reviewing this episode without mentioning the monologue of wisdom John J. Sheridan decides to record for his son. This is one of the best I've ever heard."Sleeping in Light ", evidently one of the most engaging and saddening episodes of all times, stands alone as a memoriam to the entire saga and to all it meant for so many. I shade many tears watching it. You just cannot stay indifferent to it. The episode was clearly designed to extract an emotional response from the loyal viewer, accomplishing it thoroughly.It is a look 20 years ahead from the point the show ended. Sadness is all around, to see all the characters that were 20 years younger a week ago, now at their golden years, is quite shocking.During the chapter you get innuendoes regarding the things that has happened since the curtain descended on the original series.Unfortunately, much is left a mystery, leaving you craving for more.Without telling much, I can say that Sheridan is facing the bright light, as Lorien promised after the fight with Kosh II, back in the fourth season. Hence he summons all the good old friends we know, that are still alive ,to a final nostalgic reunion.After the goodbyes he would have a few more errands to run, and then... There is one powerful image that I remember - the sunrise Delen and Sheridan share on Saturday morning, for the last time,and then their goodbye - you are left breathless.This may be the greatest achievement of them all - the success to give the viewer the feeling of a true love. To watch the two grown-ups sitting there, holding hands together, never wanting to let go - embodies the yearnings and desires of everyone.In conclusion, what was this show all about? Set aside the wars, harsh politics, intrigues, blood and tears, it was about love, and the power of love. I think that if, in the end, you feel your spirit has risen just a little bit higher, the series has accomplished its goal.

reviewText: I can't recall a television series end with the great writing and acting I found in Babylon 5's final episodes. Parting is indeed a  bittersweet sorrow; I doubt I have been more emotionally drained by the events chronicled in both episodes. In "Objects at Rest" President Sheridan (Bruce Boxleitner) and Delenn (Mira Furlon) bid farewell to Babylon 5, and head to Minbar's city of Tuzanor, the new headquarters of the Interstellar Alliance, aboard a Ranger White Star. En route, Lennier commits the act of betrayal prophesized by Mr. Morden (Eric Wasser) in the Season 5 episode "Day of the Dead". On Minbar, Sheridan and Delenn are greeted by Centauri emperor Mollari (Peter Jurasik), who speaks of his friendship, while leaving them with a deadly gift for their unborn child. In "Sleeping in Light", twenty years have passed since the end of the Shadow War and the formation of the Interstellar Alliance. Sheridan knows the end is near; he summons his surviving friends to visit him on Minbar for one last time. And so too is it the end for space station Babylon 5; fittingly enough, the station's lights are turned off by a technician played by series creator J. Michael Straczynski. "Sleeping in Light" is one of the finest affirmations of love and friendship I have seen on television; indeed, it is a splendid conclusion to the Babylon 5 saga.
summary: An Extraordinary Conclusion to the Best American SF TV Saga

reviewText: Okay, how about this for a reccomendation? I have seen most of the Babylon 5 series eight or nine times through, at least. I have only seen Sleeping in Light four times since it first aired over two years ago. Why? Because in this episode JMS creates a devastatingly moving portrait of Sheridan's final days that is just spectacular and my not watching it is a result of being that deeply affected by it. I showed this to a friend who never saw the show, she loved it. It reaches out to anyone who has ever lost a loved one and especially to the fans who knew this day was coming and never wanted to see it, but could not turn away. Series finales are usually not this powerful or tie up everything so well, but JMS performs this task excellently.Not to mention you will never look at the sunrise the same way again.

reviewText: This tape contains the last two episodes ever of Babylon 5.  In "Objects at Rest," change is coming to the station.  Franklin is leaving for Earth and his new job, Garibaldi is leaving for Mars, and Sheridan and Delenn leave for the new Alliance headquarters on Minbar.  But all does not go smoothly as Lennier makes a huge mistake and Londo arrives with a suspicious gift for Delenn's baby."Sleeping in the Light" tells the story of Sheridan's last few days.  Realizing that his time is up, he sends for his dear friends and reminisces before heading into space for one last flight.While these two episodes don't tie up all the loose ends (In fact, they raise some questions.), they are a powerful conclusion to this series.  I've watched them several times, and I've been moved by the emotions so excellently captured by everyone involved.  JMS's scripts are some of his best, and the acting is flawless.Over the run of the series, I had come to care for these characters as friends.  It was sad to see their story end.  And while it may not have had the closure I normally like, there is enough closure for a feeling of completion.  These two top-notch hours of television will move any fan of the series.
summary: Powerful Conclusion to My Favorite TV Show

reviewText: I remember as a young teenager reading J.R.R. Tolkien's "Lord of the Rings" trilogy and being amazed that such an epic saga--indeed, that a complete and convincing alternate universe--could spring from the power of human imagination. Decades later, I felt that same sense of awe and admiration upon witnessing the conclusion of the five-year television saga known as "Babylon 5." The series' two final episodes, "Objects at Rest" and "Sleeping in Light," are a fitting two-part conclusion to the epic.In "Objects at Rest," Sheridan and Delenn prepare to leave Babylon 5 for the new Interstellar Alliance headquarters on Minbar. A high point of the episode is Sheridan's moving recorded message to an unborn child. "Sleeping in Light" takes place about 20 years after "Objects," and shows Sheridan preparing to meet his prophesied destiny.These are two rich and rewarding hours of televison for loyal B5 fans. The superb cast delivers uniformly excellent performances. And the final scenes of the saga will live with me forever. My thanks to series creator J. Michael Straczynski and all those whose combined vision and talent brought this mighty epic to its emotional conclusion.
summary: An emotional conclusion to an epic saga
Title: N/A

reviewText: Through the Babylon 5 years, we have seen the range of emotions rarely seen in a miniseries that has lasted this long.  The conclusion, "Sleeping in Light" is without a doubt a soul wrenching  exploration of love, dedication, and the inevitability of prophecy.  The  time span between the previous episode and this conclusion leaves many  unanswered questions, but it appears that everything must have turned out  OK.  To see this episode in isolation may not be a good idea, but with a  little background, it can be enjoyed by anyone who has not seen the whole  series.
summary: A Magificent Conclusion to a Profound Series
